column1: FIRST HEALTH MEMORIAL HOSPITAL BUSINESS GLOSSARY

column3: DEFINITION
The particulars of the place where a patient lives. This includes house or apartment number, street name, city or town, state, and zip code.
An event that results in unintended harm to the patient by an act of commission or omission rather than by the underlying disease or condition of the patient.

Clinical data related to patient care indicating a reasonable probability that an adverse event has occurred or is occurring. An example of trigger data for an adverse drug event is a physician order for an antidote, a medication stop, or a dose decrease.
The length of time that a person has lived from the time of birth.
The month, day, and year a person was born. Example: January 20, 2000

The first person those medical personnel will contact, in case of an emergency. This person may not have the legal authority to act on a patient’s behalf to direct what kind of medical treatment a patient receives, unless explicitly provided that power.
A phone number that an emergency contact can be reached. This could be a mobile, home, or work phone number.
An illness, injury, symptom, or condition so serious that a reasonable person would seek care right away to avoid severe harm.
A personal name given to someone at birth or baptism for identification and used before a family name. Example: Ana, Mary, James, Thomas.

Data that are related to a patient’s medical history including symptoms, diagnoses, procedures, and outcomes. This can be in a form of physical exam report, lab results, X-rays, clinical information, demographic information, and health provider’s notes.
A set of information that includes insurance company’s name, address, effective date and expiration of health insurance policy, insurance ID number and insurance group number.
Care in a hospital that usually does not require an overnight stay.
Care in a hospital that requires admission as an inpatient and usually requires an overnight stay. An overnight stay for observation could be outpatient care.
Health care that you get when you are admitted as an inpatient to a health care facility, like a hospital or skilled nursing facility.
This refers to the health insurance policy number on the insurance card that indicates the coverage a health insurance provides.
This identifies a patient’s employer plan to associate with a health insurance package to see types of healthcare coverage.
The identification that an individual is given to represent the family name in the cultural system of many societies. Example: Smith, Jones, Williams, Cruz.
Insurance program that provides free or low-cost health coverage to some low-income people, families and children, pregnant women, the elderly, and people with disabilities.

The management and care of a patient to combat disease or disorder. This includes all treatments (excluding first aid, observation, and diagnostic procedures), prescription medications, wound closing devices, devices to immobilize body parts, and administration of oxygen.

A federal health insurance program for people 65 and older and certain younger people with disabilities. It also covers people with End-Stage Renal Disease (permanent kidney failure requiring dialysis or a transplant, sometimes called ESRD).

column3: A number assigned to a phone line for a specific phone that is used to call that phone. This includes home or residence phone number, mobile phone number, or work phone number. The phone number to supply should the best way contact patient or patient preference to get contacted.

A physician (M.D. – Medical Doctor or D.O. – Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine), nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist or physician assistant, as allowed under state law, who provides, coordinates, or helps a patient access a range of health care services.
The name of the health insurance company that covers a patient. The name indicates is billed first when a patient receives health care.
The provider who provided a written order for a patient to see a specialist or get certain medical services.
The name of the health insurance company that will be billed for a patient’s extended health care coverage. This works together with the primary health insurance for coordinated benefits.
The physical differences between people who are “male,” “female,” or intersex that is typically assigned at birth.

A personally identifiable information. This is a numerical identifier that is uniquely assigned by the US Government to US citizens, and other residents to easily identify individuals within the Social Security system. This is also used to identify patients for identity verification when looking up health records and for payment collection for healthcare services. Example: 123-45-6789
